unit.description: Discover the immortal soul within you and learn the art of wise action through Krishna's foundational teachings.

sections.keyTeaching: You are not your body‚Äîthe soul is eternal and unchanging
Master your reactions to become truly wise
Focus and self-control create lasting peace

content.scenario: You lose a precious family heirloom that has been in your family for generations. You feel devastated, as if a part of you has died. What is the truest perspective?

options.text: My identity is broken because the object is gone.
options.feedback: This is attachment to the temporary. Objects define us only if we let them.

options.text: The object is gone, but the love and memory‚Äîand I myself‚Äîremain untouched.
options.feedback: Correct. The essence is never lost, only the form changes.

content.title: Krishna Speaks
content.story: With Arjuna sitting dejected in the chariot, Krishna smiled gently. 'You speak wise words,' Krishna said, 'yet you grieve for those who need no grief.' Arjuna looked up confused. 'The wise grieve neither for the living nor the dead,' Krishna continued. 'For there was never a time when you, or I, or any of these warriors did not exist. Nor will there ever be a time when we cease to exist.'
content.krishnaMessage: Death is just a change of clothes for the eternal soul.

content.questionText: According to Krishna, why should the wise not grieve?
options: Because grief is a sign of weakness
Because the soul is eternal and never truly dies
Because death is just bad luck
Because they don't care about others
content.explanation: Krishna's core teaching is that our true self‚Äîthe Atman or soul‚Äîis eternal. It was never born and will never die. When we understand this, fear of death loses its power over us.
content.realLifeApplication: When we understand that our essence is eternal, we approach life's challenges with more courage and less fear.

content.scenario: You notice your first grey hairs and wrinkles. You feel a sudden panic about getting old. How does the soul perspective help?

options.text: It doesn't; getting old is terrible.
options.feedback: This view identifies you completely with the decaying body.

options.text: It helps me realize that while my body changes, the 'I' who observes it remains young and timeless.
options.feedback: Yes! The observer (the soul) does not age. Only the vehicle (the body) does.

content.prompt: If you truly believed you had existed forever and would continue to exist forever, how would that change how you live today?
content.krishnaWisdom: Fear of death is the root of most human suffering. Understanding your eternal nature frees you.

content.scenario: You are sitting in a noisy cafe. Chaos is everywhere. Can you find a part of yourself that is just watching the noise without being the noise?

options.text: No, I am the noise. It annoys me.
options.feedback: This is being lost in the experience.

options.text: Yes, I can observe the sounds coming and going while remaining still.
options.feedback: That stillness is the witness consciousness‚Äîthe reflection of the soul.

content.title: The Witness Consciousness
content.story: Krishna teaches that the soul is not the doer, but the witness. Imagine a movie screen. Tragedies, comedies, wars, and romances play on it. The screen shows them all but is never burned by fire in the movie or wet by water. In the same way, your soul witnesses your life's drama without being damaged by it.
content.krishnaMessage: Be the screen, not the movie.

content.questionText: The soul is compared to what in this lesson?
options: The screen that witnesses the movie
content.explanation: The witness (Sakshi) merely observes. It allows experience to happen but is not entangled in it.
content.realLifeApplication: Next time you are angry, try to 'watch' your anger instead of 'being' angry. That step back is the witness.

content.scenario: You have a bad headache. It hurts a lot. How can the 'Witness' perspective help?

options.text: By pretending the pain doesn't exist.
options.feedback: Denial isn't witnessing. Witnessing acknowledges reality.

options.text: By noticing 'There is a sensation of pain' rather than screaming 'I am in pain!'
options.feedback: Exactly. Creating subject-object separation reduces suffering.

content.prompt: Try to sit quietly for one minute. Watch your thoughts pass by like clouds in the sky. Can you see that 'You' are the sky, not the clouds?
content.krishnaWisdom: Thoughts come and go. The One who knows the thoughts remains.

content.scenario: You are moving to a new city and feel terrified of leaving your old life behind. How would Krishna advise you?

options.text: Don't go if you are scared.
options.feedback: Growth requires change.

options.text: See it as changing clothes‚Äîthe essence remains, only the setting changes.
options.feedback: Correct. We change roles and places, but the Soul continues its journey.

content.title: The Most Famous Verse
content.story: 'Just as a person casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones,' Krishna explained, 'the soul casts off worn-out bodies and enters new ones.' This simple analogy has comforted millions for thousands of years. You don't mourn when you throw away old clothes‚Äîyou look forward to new ones. Death is just the soul's wardrobe change.
content.krishnaMessage: You are not your body. You are the one wearing it.

content.questionText: In Krishna's analogy, what is the body compared to?
options: Clothes that we wear and change
content.explanation: This is Bhagavad Gita verse 2.22, one of the most quoted verses. Krishna uses the relatable example of changing clothes to explain reincarnation. Just as we don't cry when we change clothes, we shouldn't fear the soul's change of bodies.
content.realLifeApplication: This perspective helps us approach both life transitions and eventual death with more peace.

content.scenario: You lose your title at work. You feel 'naked' without it. What is the truth?

options.text: I am nothing without my title.
options.feedback: That was just a coat you were wearing.

options.text: The title was just a garment. I am still whole.
options.feedback: Yes. Roles are garments the soul wears for a time.

content.prompt: What 'clothes' (roles, titles, appearances) are you most attached to? How would it feel to take them off?
content.krishnaWisdom: We are often most attached to the costumes that fit us least.

content.scenario: You have a job interview for your dream position. You've prepared for weeks and really need this job. How should you approach it according to the Gita's teaching?

options.text: Don't care about the outcome at all‚Äîwhatever happens, happens
options.feedback: This sounds like detachment but is actually apathy. Krishna never said don't care‚Äîhe said don't be obsessed with controlling what you can't control.

options.text: Focus on giving your absolute best in the interview, accept whatever result comes
options.feedback: Perfect! This is Karma Yoga in action. You control your preparation and performance. The hiring decision involves factors beyond your control. Do your best, then release attachment to the outcome.

options.text: Visualize getting the job constantly to manifest it
options.feedback: Constant focus on the result creates anxiety and pressure. Krishna teaches us to focus on our action, not obsess over outcomes.

content.title: The Secret of Work
content.story: Krishna now reveals one of the Gita's most practical teachings‚Äîhow to work without stress. 'You have the right to work only,' he says, 'but never to its fruits. Let not the fruits of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.' In other words: Do your best, but don't be obsessed with results. And don't use non-attachment as an excuse to do nothing!
content.krishnaMessage: Excellence comes when we focus on the process, not just the prize.

content.questionText: According to verse 2.47, what is our right?
options: Only to the fruits of our actions
Only to work, never to its fruits
content.explanation: Verse 2.47 is perhaps the Gita's most famous teaching. We can control our effort but not outcomes. This isn't passive acceptance‚Äîit's freedom from the anxiety of results while still giving our best.
content.realLifeApplication: Students stress about grades. Athletes stress about winning. This teaching helps us focus on what we can control‚Äîour effort and attitude.

content.scenario: You are writing a book but you're stuck because you keep worrying if people will like it. What is the solution?

options.text: Stop writing until you know it will sell.
options.feedback: Attachment to inaction.

options.text: Write for the joy of writing, letting go of the audience's reaction.
options.feedback: Yes. When you remove the pressure of the 'fruit', the work flows naturally.

content.prompt: What work or project is stressing you out right now? How much of that stress comes from worrying about the result versus doing the work itself?
content.krishnaWisdom: Work done with anxiety is toil. Work done with detachment is worship.

content.scenario: You are doing three things at once, doing none of them well, and feeling frantic. Is this Yoga?

options.text: Yes, I am being very productive.
options.feedback: Activity helps, but frantic activity is not skill.

options.text: No, Yoga is 'Skill in Action'‚Äîdoing one thing with full presence and mastery.
options.feedback: Correct. Scattering energy is the opposite of Yoga.

content.title: What Is Yoga, Really?
content.story: Many people think yoga means physical postures. But Krishna gives a revolutionary definition: 'Yoga is skill in action.' It's not about running away from the world‚Äîit's about mastering how you engage with it. A person who works with full focus, without anxiety about results, without ego claiming credit‚Äîthat person is a true yogi, even while living a normal life.
content.krishnaMessage: You don't need to leave the world to find peace. Transform how you act within it.

content.questionText: According to the Gita, what is 'Yoga'?
content.explanation: 'Yogah karmasu kaushalam' (2.50)‚ÄîYoga is skill in action. This means performing your duties with excellence while maintaining inner balance.
content.realLifeApplication: You practice yoga every time you work with full attention, do your best, and let go of obsessive anxiety about results.

content.scenario: You need to give critical feedback to a sensitive colleague. How does a Yogi approach this?

options.text: Avoid it to keep peace.
options.feedback: Avoidance is fear, not yoga.

options.text: Deliver the truth with compassion and without anger, detached from their reaction.
options.feedback: Yes. Skill in action means doing the hard thing with the right mindstate.

content.prompt: Pick one mundane task you do every day (washing dishes, walking, typing). Try doing it today as 'Yoga'‚Äîwith total focus and no mind-wandering. How does it feel different?
content.krishnaWisdom: Even the smallest act becomes sacred when done with full awareness.

content.prompt: Placeholder for Lesson 2.2.3: Free from Anxiety
content.krishnaWisdom: Wisdom born of karma yoga releases us from the bondage of rebirth.

content.scenario: In the morning meeting, your boss praises you. In the afternoon, a client yells at you. How does the 'Sthitaprajna' react?

options.text: High in the morning, crushed in the afternoon.
options.feedback: This is being a slave to external events.

options.text: Accepts praise without arrogance and criticism without depression.
options.feedback: Correct. Steady wisdom implies an internal anchor that storms don't move.

content.title: What Does Wisdom Look Like?
content.story: Arjuna asks a practical question: 'Krishna, how can I recognize a truly wise person? How do they sit? How do they walk? How do they speak?' Krishna's answer defines the 'Sthitaprajna'‚Äîone who is stable in wisdom. Such a person is not moved by pleasure or pain. They have no cravings, no fear, no attachment. They are like a lamp that doesn't flicker in a windless place.
content.krishnaMessage: Wisdom isn't about knowing more‚Äîit's about being unshakeable.

options: A person stable in wisdom, unmoved by pleasure or pain
A person who lives in forest
content.explanation: Sthitaprajna literally means 'steady-minded'. Such a person has emotional stability‚Äînot because they don't feel, but because they're not controlled by feelings.
content.realLifeApplication: This is emotional intelligence at its highest‚Äîfeeling emotions without being ruled by them.

content.scenario: You suddenly win a huge amount of money. What is the danger?

options.text: That I will lose it.
options.feedback: Fear accompanies attachment.

options.text: That the extreme excitement will unbalance my mind and lead to bad decisions.
options.feedback: Yes. Extreme pleasure can be as destabilizing as extreme pain. The wise stay centered.

content.prompt: Recall a time you were 'knocked off balance' by strong emotion. What would have helped you stay steady like a lamp in a windless place?
content.krishnaWisdom: Balance is power. Adaptation is strength.

content.prompt: Placeholder for Lesson 2.3.2: The Unshakable Mind
content.krishnaWisdom: He who is unmoved by good or evil fortune is firmly fixed in perfect knowledge.

content.scenario: You are at a feast. You are full, but the dessert looks amazing. Your senses say 'eat', your intelligence says 'stop'. What do you do?

options.text: Eat it anyway, life is short.
options.feedback: This is slavery to the senses.

options.text: Withdraw my desire like a turtle warming its limbs.
options.feedback: Correct. Mastering the urge is sweeter than the dessert.

content.title: The Turtle Wisdom
content.story: Krishna gives a beautiful metaphor: 'As a tortoise withdraws its limbs into its shell, so the wise person withdraws their senses from sense objects.' This isn't about suppressing your senses forever‚Äîit's about having the ability to pull them back when needed. A turtle doesn't cut off its limbs; it simply knows when to pull them in.
content.krishnaMessage: Mastery is not about never experiencing pleasure. It's about not being enslaved by it.

content.questionText: Why does Krishna use the turtle metaphor?
options: To teach us to move slowly
To show how to hide from problems
To illustrate withdrawing senses at will
To teach us to carry heavy loads
content.explanation: Verse 2.58's turtle metaphor is about conscious control. It's not repression; it's the ability to disengage from sensory stimulation when it's harmful or distracting.
content.realLifeApplication: Putting your phone in 'Do Not Disturb' mode is a modern act of the Turtle.

content.scenario: You plan to study, but your phone keeps buzzing. You feel the urge to check it. What is the Turtle move?

options.text: Check it quickly so I can focus.
options.feedback: Feeding the distraction usually grows it.

options.text: Turn it off and put it in another room.
options.feedback: Yes. Physically withdrawing the sense object makes mental withdrawal easier.

content.prompt: What is your 'kryptonite'‚Äîthe one thing you have trouble withdrawing from? Food, phone, gossip? Imagine putting a 'shell' around yourself next time you face it.
content.krishnaWisdom: Strength is the ability to say 'no' to yourself.

content.scenario: You've been scrolling through social media and seeing friends' vacation photos. You start feeling inadequate and angry. According to Krishna's teaching about the chain of desire, what is the wisest response?

options.text: Keep scrolling to distract yourself
options.feedback: This feeds the cycle. Comparison -> Desire -> Anger.

options.text: Recognize the trigger, put down the phone, refocus on your own path
options.feedback: This breaks the chain at the link of 'contemplation'.

content.title: The Chain of Destruction
content.story: Krishna reveals the dangerous chain reaction that starts with unchecked desire: 'When you constantly think about something, attachment arises. From attachment comes desire. From desire comes anger (when blocked). From anger comes delusion. From delusion comes loss of memory. From memory loss, intelligence is destroyed. And when intelligence is destroyed, one perishes.' It's a domino effect that starts with what we allow our minds to dwell on.
content.krishnaMessage: Guard the gate of your mind. What you let in, grows.

content.questionText: According to verses 2.62-63, what is the first step in the chain that leads to destruction?
content.explanation: It all starts with what we choose to focus on (Dhyayato vishayan). When we constantly dwell on something, attachment forms.
content.realLifeApplication: This is why social media can be dangerous‚Äîconstant exposure to curated images creates desired comparison.

content.scenario: You keep checking the profile of someone you like, fantasizing about a future with them. You notice you're getting jealous seeing them with others. What stage of the chain are you in?

options.text: Just harmless fun.
options.feedback: Denial. The jealousy proves attachment has already formed.

options.text: Attachment turning into Desire and potential Anger.
options.feedback: Correct. You are dangerously close to the 'crash'. Time to step back.

content.prompt: What do you find yourself thinking about repeatedly? What 'sense objects' (material things, achievements, relationships) occupy your mind? Is this focus serving you or creating suffering?
content.krishnaWisdom: You become what you think about. Choose your mental diet wisely.

content.prompt: Placeholder for Lesson 2.4.2: No Peace Without Focus
content.krishnaWisdom: There is no intelligence where there is no concentration.

content.prompt: Placeholder for Lesson 2.4.3: Like the Ocean
content.krishnaWisdom: As the ocean remains unmoved by entering rivers, so the wise remain unmoved by desires.
